In the case of BGP, using the TCP MD5 Signature Option and anti-spoofing measures can mitigate the vulnerability.

Other applications, such as Domain Name System (DNS) and (Secure Sockets Layer) SSL based applications may also be affected, but to a lesser degree, the report said.

A remote user can reportedly send a TCP packet with the RST (reset) flag set (or the SYN flag) with the appropriate spoofed source and destination IP addresses and TCP ports to cause the TCP session to be terminated.  Ordinarily, the remote user may have the probability of 1 in 2^32 of guessing the correct sequence number, the report said.  However, in actuality, a remote user may be able to guess an appropriate sequence number with much greater probability because many implementations will accept any sequence number within a certain window of the expected sequence number.  The Associate Press reports that the proper number can be guessed within as few as four attempts, requiring only seconds to achieve.

The report credits Paul A. Watson for discovering a practical method for conducting TCP reset attacks (presented in "Slipping In The Window: TCP Reset Attacks" at the CanSecWest 2004 conference).

The report indicates that the following vendors are affected [this is not an inclusive list]:

- Cray Inc. is vulnerable on their UNICOS, UNICOS/mk and UNICOS/mp systems

- Check Point is affected, but has issued a protection mechanism in the latest release for VPN-1/FireWall-1 (R55 HFA-03) that can protect both the firewall device and hosts located behind the firewall.

- Internet Initiative Japan, Inc (IIJ) is affected.

- InterNiche NicheStack and NicheLite are affected.

- Juniper Networks products are affected.

- Cisco products are affected, including IOS and non-IOS based devices.

Other vendors are assessing the impact of this flaw.

The NISCC Vulnerability Advisory 236929 is available at:

http://www.uniras.gov.uk/vuls/2004/236929/index.htm
Impact': A remote user can cause denial of service on the target TCP session.  The specific impact depends on the specific vendor implementation.
Solution:
Blue Coat Systems has issued a fix for CacheOS.

For CacheOS CA 4.1.X, upgrading to SG2 or SG3 patches is recommended by the vendor.

For CacheOS SA 4.1.X, upgrading to SG3 patch is recommended by the vendor.

Title: NetCache Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Network Appliance Data ONTAP and NetCache products.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
Secunia reported that Network Appliance disclosed an unspecified flaw that can be triggered by the network effects of an unspecified worm.  A remote user can cause the device to panic and reboot, the report indicated.

The vendor has reportedly assigned bug id #130383 to this issue.
Impact': A remote user can cause the device to panic and reboot.
Solution: The vendor has reportedly issued a patch, but [according to the report] is uncertain whether the patch corrects the flaw or not.

Title: (HP Carrier Grade Servers are Affected) Intel Server Setup Utilities May Let Remote Users Access Motherboard Utility Functions
Version(s): HP Carrier Grade Server cc2300, cc3300, cc3310
Description:
A configuration vulnerability was reported in several Intel server setup utilities, including the System Setup Utility (SSU), Client System Setup Utility (CSSU), Server Configuration Wizard (SCW), and CLI Auto-configuration Utility. A remote user can gain access to some utility functions.  Some HP Carrier Grade Servers are affected.
Intel reported that the affected server setup utilities may cause an invalid firmware setting to be configured, allowing a remote user to gain access to certain offline utilities (if LAN Management is enabled).

The following HP systems are affected:

  HP carrier grade server cc2300 - A6898A, A6899A

  HP carrier grade server cc3300 - A6900A, A6901A

  HP carrier grade server cc3310 - A9862A, A9863A
Impact': A remote user may be able to access the utilities if LAN Management is enabled.
Solution:
HP recommends that customers that have enabled LAN management download the Intel BmcLanFix utility and run it to correct the vulnerability on servers that have IPMI based LAN management enabled.  The utility must be run whenever enabling LAN Management, the vendor said.  In addition, the utility must be reapplied whenever the configuration is saved while LAN Management is enabled.

The BmcLanFix utility and instructions are available at:

http://support.intel.com/support/motherboards/server/sb/CS-010422.htm

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) APC SmartSlot Card Backdoor Password Lets Remote Users Obtain Usernames and Passwords
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the APC SmartSlot management cards used by various APC SmartSwitch and UPS products.  A remote user can gain access to the device.
It is reported that the APC SmartSlot Web/SNMP management cards include a common 'backdoor' password ('TENmanUFactOryPOWER') used for factory initialization.  A remote user can reportedly access the system via the telnet port or the local serial port using this account and dump the EEPROM contents, which includes usernames and passwords.  Then, the remote user can login using one of the accounts to gain access to the device.

The following systems were tested to be vulnerable:

SmartUPS 3000RM with AP9606 AOS v3.2.1 and SmartUPS App v3.2.6
MasterSwitch AP9212 with AP9606 AOS v3.0.3 and MasterSwitch App v2.2.0

The vendor was reportedly notified on August 12, 2003.
Impact': A remote user can obtain usernames and passwords from the system.
Solution:
The vendor has released patches for some of the affected products.  A patch matrix is provided in the Source Message and in the vendor's advisory at:

http://www.apc.com/go/direct/index.cfm?tag=sa2988

Update patches are available at:

http://www.apc.com/go/direct/index.cfm?tag=sa2988_patch

The following devices are confirmed to be affected:

    AP9606 Web/SNMP Management Card
    AP9617 Network Management Card EX
    AP9618 Network Management Card EM/MDM
    AP9619 Network Management Card EM

The vendor reports that APC Network Management Cards (models AP9617, AP9618, and AP9619) using AOS v2.0.0 (apc_hw02_aos_200.bin) and later are not affected.

APC states that they will not provide patches for the following products:

SmartSlot SNMP Management Adapter (AP9605)
External SNMP Management Adapter(AP9205)
Token Ring Management Card (AP9603)

If you have those products, the vendor recommends that you disable any Telnet interface if present or remove the network connection from the card.

Title: APC SmartSlot Card Backdoor Password Lets Remote Users Obtain Usernames and Passwords
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the APC SmartSlot management cards used by various APC SmartSwitch and UPS products.  A remote user can gain access to the device.
It is reported that the APC SmartSlot Web/SNMP management cards include a common 'backdoor' password ('TENmanUFactOryPOWER') used for factory initialization.  A remote user can reportedly access the system via the telnet port or the local serial port using this account and dump the EEPROM contents, which includes usernames and passwords.  Then, the remote user can login using one of the accounts to gain access to the device.

The following systems were tested to be vulnerable:

SmartUPS 3000RM with AP9606 AOS v3.2.1 and SmartUPS App v3.2.6
MasterSwitch AP9212 with AP9606 AOS v3.0.3 and MasterSwitch App v2.2.0

The vendor was reportedly notified on August 12, 2003.
Impact': A remote user can obtain usernames and passwords from the system.
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor is reportedly working on a patch.

The author of the report indicates that as a workaround, you can restrict physical access to the local serial port and disable the telnet interface as described in the device documentation.

Title: (Sun Issues Fix for Cobalt RaQ) GnuPG ElGamal Signature Flaw May Disclose Type 20 ElGamal Private Keys to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in GnuPG in the creation of ElGamal keys for digital signature.  Keys used for signing can be compromised.
It is reported that Phong Nguyen discovered a flaw that allows a remote user to determine your private key within a few seconds.

In version 1.0.2 (January 2000), the flaw was introduced when the GnuPG code was modified to improve the efficiency of encryption using ElGamal keys.  A common factor was used for encrypting and signing.  As a result, a remtote user with access to a target user's signature can conduct a cryptographic attack to determine the target user's private key.  This flaw reportedly affects only ElGamal sign+encrypt keys (type 20) in GnuPG version 1.0.2 and later.

The vendor reports that ElGamal encrypt-only keys (type 16) are not affected.  Also, the DSA keys and RSA keys are not vulnerable, according to the report.
Impact': A remote user can determine the ElGamal private key.
Solution:
Sun has issued GnuPG Security Update 1.0.1 for Cobalt RaQ, available at:

http://ftp.cobalt.sun.com/pub/packages/raqxtr/eng/RaQXTR-All-Security-1.0.1-16674.pkg

There are reportedly no Pre-Requisites and no reboot required.

MD5 Check Sum: 6f84f67daf2b2ff766f01b88033b2307

Title: (Sun Issues Fix for Cobalt RaQ) GNU/Linux '/bin/ls' Memory Allocation May Let Remote Users Deny Service Via Other Applications
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the GNU/Linux 'ls' utility.  A remote user may be able to cause denial of service conditions by exploiting /bin/ls via remote applications, such as wu-ftpd.
Georgi Guninski reported an integer overflow in /bin/ls.  Also, applications that invoke /bin/ls may be subject to denial of service attacks, the report said.  A remote user may be able to cause an application (such as wu-ftpd) to invoke ls with the '-w' column width option and the '-C' option to consume a large amount of memory for a temporary period of time.  The init_column_info() function will potentially allocate much more memory than is needed to display the relevant files.  This can reportedly cause temporary denial of service conditions.

As a demonstration exploit of the memory consumption flaw, the following command can be used via wu-ftpd:

ls "-w 1000000 -C"

As a demonstration exploit for the integer overflow flaw, the following local command can be used:

/bin/ls -w 1073741828 -C

The /bin/ls utility is part of the GNU coreutils collection.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.guninski.com/binls.html
Impact': A remote user may be able to cause applications using /bin/ls to experience denial of service conditions.
Solution:
Sun has issued Fileutils Security Update 1.0.1 for Cobalt RaQ.

HTTP RaQXTR-All-Security-1.0.1-16648.pkg Posted:October 01, 2004:

http://ftp.cobalt.sun.com/pub/packages/raqxtr/eng/RaQXTR-All-Security-1.0.1-16648.pkg

There are no pre-requisites and no reboot required.

MD5 Check Sum: 439e9e955325e12ff69b2fec86f5bb82

Title: (Cisco Emergency Responder is Affected) Microsoft Windows Workstation Service (wkssvc.dll) Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code with System Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Cisco reported that Cisco Emergency Responder appliances are affected by the Windows 2000 Workstation Service vulnerability. A remote user can execute arbitrary code with System privileges on the target system.
It is reported that a remote user can send a specially crafted message to the Workstation service to cause the service to crash or execute arbitrary code with System level privileges.  Other attack vectors can reportedly be used.  For example, a remote authenticated user can login and send malformed messages to the service or an application that passes messages to the service can be exploited.

The flaw exists in the Wkssvc.dll file.

The Workstation service is used to route local file system requests and remote file or print network requests and is enabled by default, according to the report.

Microsoft indicates that if you have blocked inbound UDP ports 138, 139, 445 and TCP ports 138, 139, 445 with a firewall, a remote user cannot send messages to the Workstation service.

Microsoft credits eEye Digital Security with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target system with System privileges.
Solution:
Cisco has issued a fix for affected Cisco IP Telephony Applications: for all versions of Cisco CallManager and all compatible versions of Cisco IP Interactive Voice Response (IP IVR), Cisco IP Call Center Express (IPCC Express), Cisco Personal Assistant (PA), Cisco Emergency Responder (CER), Cisco Conference Connection (CCC), and Cisco Internet Service Node (ISN).  The vendor advises customers to apply the win-OS-Upgrade-k9.2000-2-5sr4.exe or later package located at the following URL:

http://www.cisco.com/pcgi-bin/tablebuild.pl/cmva-3des?psrtdcat20e2

Title: Canon VB-C10R Network Camera Input Validation Flaw Permits Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the Canon VB-C10R Network Camera.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks.
It is reported that the built-in web server does not filter user-supplied HTML from HTTP requests before displaying the user-supplied request URL when an invalid page is requested.  A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the Network Camera and will run in the security context of the camera. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user. 

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://198.182.xxx.xxx:80/<SCRIPT>alert('Vulnerable')</SCRIPT>.jsp

The vendor was reportedly notified on November 28, 2003.
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the network camera, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the camera, or take actions on the camera acting as the target user.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Symbol Technologies PDT 8100 Default WEP Keys May Grant Remote Users Access to the Network
Description:
A default configuration vulnerability was reported in the Symbol Technologies PDT 8100 portable data terminal.  A remote user can gain access to the target user's network.
SECNAP Network Security reported that the system uses common default wireless encryption protocol (WEP) keys and permits the user to view the default keys.

If the user does not change the default keys, a remote user can gain access to the wireless network.

The following notification timeline is provided:

AutomedRX Nov 6, 2003
Symbol Technologies,  Nov 7, 2003
Cert, Nov 7, 2003
Released: November 10, 2003
Impact': A remote user can gain access to the target user's network.
Solution: The report indicates that the vendor recommends that the user change all default passwords and keys during installation.

Title: (Sun Issues Fix for Cobalt RaQ) Re: Linux Kernel ptrace() Flaw Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.2 and 2.4 kernels.  A local user can obtain root privileges on the system.
According to the report, the vulnerable resides in the ptrace() function.  No details were summarized in the report.

The vendor indicates that the 2.5 kernel is not affected.

The vendor credits Andrzej Szombierski for reporting the flaw.
Impact': A local user can obtain root privileges.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fixes for the Cobalt RaQ devices:

RaQ XTR with RaQXTR-All-Kernel-1.0.1-2.2.16C37_V-1-2.pkg, available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/patches/cobalt

RaQ4 with RaQ4-All-Kernel-2.0.1-2.2.16C37-III-1-2.pkg, available at: 

http://ftp.cobalt.sun.com/pub/packages/raq4/eng/RaQ4-All-Kernel-2.0.1-2.2.16C37-III-1-2.pkg)

RaQ550 with RaQ550-All-Kernel-0.0.1-2.4.19C7_V-1-3.pkg, available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/patches/cobalt

Title: (Sun Issues Fix for Cobalt Qube) Re: Linux Kernel ptrace() Flaw Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linux 2.2 and 2.4 kernels.  A local user can obtain root privileges on the system.
According to the report, the vulnerable resides in the ptrace() function.  No details were summarized in the report.

The vendor indicates that the 2.5 kernel is not affected.

The vendor credits Andrzej Szombierski for reporting the flaw.
Impact': A local user can obtain root privileges.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fix for the Cobalt Qube:

Qube3 with Qube3-All-Kernel-4.0.1-2.2.16C37-III-1.pkg, available at:

http://sunsolve.sun.com/patches/cobalt

Title: Sun Cobalt RaQ 'message.cgi' Input Validation Flaw Permits Remote Cross-Site Scripting Attacks Against Administrators
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Lorenzo Hernandez Garcia-Hierro of NSRGroup reported some input validation vulnerabilities in the Sun Cobalt RaQ web-based control panel.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks against RaQ administrators.
It is reported that the 'message.cgi' script does not properly validate user-supplied input in the 'info' parameter.  As a result, a remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target administrator, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target administrator's browser. The code will originate from the control panel and will run in the security context of the control panel. As a result, the code will be able to access the target administrator's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the control panel, access data recently submitted by the target administrator via web form to the control panel, or take actions on the control panel acting as the target administrator.

A demonstration exploit is of the following form:

HTTP://[HOST NAME / DOMAIN]:[PORT: 81]/cgi-bin/.cobalt/message/message.cgi?info=[SCRIPT / XSS CODE]

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can access the target administrator's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the control panel, access data recently submitted by the target administrator via web form to the control panel, or take actions on the control panel acting as the target administrator.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Sun Ray Smartcard Authentication Flaw May Allow Sessions to Persist After Removal of the Card
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Sun Ray Server Software for Solaris.  The software may allow an authenticated session to persist even after the Sun Ray Smartcard has been removed.
It is reported that the process of quickly removing, reinserting, and removing a Smartcard in the Sun Ray Smartcard reader may result in the authenticated login session staying connected to the Desk Top Unit (DTU), even though the card has been removed.  This occurs only rarely, according to Sun.

Sun indicates that the flaw is firmware bug in the Sun Ray reader.
Impact': A physically local user may be able to gain access to a login session after the Sun Ray Smartcard has been removed.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.  Sun is working on a final resolution.

As a workaround, Sun advises that you should make sure that the session associated with the Smartcard is not still displayed on the screen when you remove the card.

Title: Replicom ProxyView Default Configuration Gives Remote Users Full Access
Description:
A configuration vulnerability was reported in Replicom's ProxyView.  A remote user can access the device if a common default password has not been changed.
It is reported that a remote user can connect to the NetBIOS port and login with the default password of 'Administrator' for the 'Administrator' operating system (OS) account (the product uses Embedded Windows NT).  The presence of this default setting is not documented, according to the report.  Note that this OS-level account is different than the default ProxyView administrator application-level account.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can gain full Administrator operating system access on the device.
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report has provided the following solution steps:

1) Generate a new password.

2) Modify the following registry key to contain the new password:

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon

3) Connect to the ProxyView and change the Administrator password.

The author of the report warns that if the 'autologon' password and the Administrator password are not the same, the ProxyView device will not function after it has been rebooted.  If this occurs, you can reportedly access the device via NetBIOS to correct the problem.

Title: (Sun Issues Fix for Cobalt Qube) Re: Apache mod_ssl 'Off-by-One' Bug May Let Local Users Crash the Web Server or Possibly Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in mod_ssl.  A local user that can create '.htaccess' files may be able to cause mod_ssl to crash or execute arbitrary code on the system with the privileges of the web server.
An 'off-by-one' error has been reported in mod_ssl.  The flaw reportedly exists in the  ssl_compat_directive() while invoking the Apache web server rewrite_command extended API (EAPI) hook.  According to the report, when backward compatibility is enabled, mod_ssl registers a rewrite_command hook and calls the ssl_compat_directive() function for every line read in a configuration file.

A local user that can create a '.htaccess' file on the web server can place specially crafted information in the file to cause Apache mod_ssl to execute arbitrary code when reading the file (e.g., when a remote user attempts to access a file in a directory protected by the '.htaccess' file).

Servers that allow virtual hosts and have the "AllowOverride" directive not set to "None" for virtual hosts may be affected if local users have access to any part of the web directory.  Other configurations may also be vulnerable.

According to the report, mod_ssl compiled without backward compatibility is not vulnerable.  However, the backward compatibility feature is reportedly enabled by default during compilation.
Impact': A local user could cause denial of service conditions or could possibly execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the web server.
Solution:
Sun has released a fix for the Sun Cobalt Qube3(4000WG):

Qube3-All-Security-4.0.1-15787.pkg

Title: (Sun Issues Fix for Cobalt RaQ) Re: Apache mod_ssl 'Off-by-One' Bug May Let Local Users Crash the Web Server or Possibly Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): RaQ3(3000R), ManageRaQ3(3000R-mr), RaQ4(3001R), RaQ XTR(3500R), RaQ 550 (4100R)
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in mod_ssl.  A local user that can create '.htaccess' files may be able to cause mod_ssl to crash or execute arbitrary code on the system with the privileges of the web server.
An 'off-by-one' error has been reported in mod_ssl.  The flaw reportedly exists in the  ssl_compat_directive() while invoking the Apache web server rewrite_command extended API (EAPI) hook.  According to the report, when backward compatibility is enabled, mod_ssl registers a rewrite_command hook and calls the ssl_compat_directive() function for every line read in a configuration file.

A local user that can create a '.htaccess' file on the web server can place specially crafted information in the file to cause Apache mod_ssl to execute arbitrary code when reading the file (e.g., when a remote user attempts to access a file in a directory protected by the '.htaccess' file).

Servers that allow virtual hosts and have the "AllowOverride" directive not set to "None" for virtual hosts may be affected if local users have access to any part of the web directory.  Other configurations may also be vulnerable.

According to the report, mod_ssl compiled without backward compatibility is not vulnerable.  However, the backward compatibility feature is reportedly enabled by default during compilation.
Impact': A local user could cause denial of service conditions or could possibly execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the web server.
Solution:
Sun has released the following fixes for Sun Cobalt RaQ.

RaQ3(3000R):

RaQ3-All-Security-4.0.1-1-15787.pkg


ManageRaQ3(3000R-mr):

RaQ3-All-Security-4.0.1-1-15787.pkg


RaQ4(3001R):

RaQ4-All-Security-2.0.1-2-15787.pkg


RaQ XTR(3500R):

RaQXTR-All-Security-1.0.1-15787.pkg


RaQ 550 (4100R):

RaQ550-All-Security-0.0.1-15787.pkg

Title: (Sun Issues Fix) Re: Sun Cobalt RaQ 4 Security Hardening Package CGI Input Validation Flaw Lets Remote Users Gain Root Access
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Sun Cobalt RaQ4 appliance with the Security Hardening Package installed.  A remote user can gain root privileges on the system.
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the Cobalt administrative interface when the Security Hardening Package is installed. The vulnerability is reported in the overflow cgi script (/cgi-bin/.cobalt/overflow/overflow.cgi), where the 'email' variable is not properly filtered.  A remote user can submit a POST request to this cgi script with a specially crafted command in the 'email' variable.  Then, the remote user can call the overflowTestEmail.cgi script to cause the server to execute the previously supplied command with root privileges.

A demonstration exploit script is available in the Source Message [it is Base64 encoded].
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary shell commands on the system with root privileges on the system.
Solution:
Sun reports that the Sun Cobalt RaQ 4 with patch RaQ4-SHP Release 1.x.x is vulnerable.  Sun notes that you can verify if this patch is installed by logging in to the Sun Cobalt Web GUI and clicking on the "Maintenance" tab at the left side of the screen. Then click on the "Installed Software" bullet at the top of the screen and see if a patch similar to "RaQ4-SHP Release 1.x.x" is shown.  If so, your system is vulnerable. 

Sun has issued the following patch:

http://ftp.cobalt.sun.com/pub/packages/raq4/eng/RaQ4-en-Security-2.0.1-SHP_REM.pkg

http://ftp.cobalt.sun.com/pub/packages/raq4/eng/RaQ4-en-Security-2.0.1-SHP_REM.pkg

Title: (Sun Issues Fix) Re: Sun Cobalt Qube /usr/lib/authenticate Bug Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in /usr/lib/authenticate on Sun's Cobalt RaQ and Qube platforms.  A local user could gain root privileges.
Sun did not disclose the nature of the vulnerability.  No further details were provided.

Sun Cobalt Control Station (SCCS) is also reportedly affected.
Impact': A local user could gain root privileges on the system.
Solution:
Sun has issued the following fix for Qube3:

http://ftp.cobalt.sun.com/pub/packages/qube3/ml/Qube3-All-Security-4.0.1-15787.pkg

Title: (Vendor Develops Fix) Re: Allot's NetEnforcer Holes Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges on the System
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in Allot's NetEnforcer network and application performance management system.  A local user can gain elevated privileges on the device.  A remote user may be able to gain access if the common default passwords have not been changed.
A remote user may be able to gain access to the system using common default passwords for the following accounts:  root, admin, monitor.

The following flaws can be exploited by a remote authenticated user.

A remote user with authenticated access to the 'monitor' account can user the ssh -N option (do not execute a remote command) to cause the NetEnforcer ssh daemon to forward traffic from the remote user.

A remote user can exploit the above listed flaw to access the NetEnforcer MySQL server on port 53305.  Remote access to this port is only permitted for local users 'root' and 'mysql', but the port forwarding flaw makes the access appear to be local so that a remote user (who has obtain a password for the 'admin' account) can access the MySQL server:

ssh admin@netenforcer -L 1919:127.0.0.1:53306 -v
..
mysql -h localhost -P 1919 -u root

With this access, the user can load data from the local filesystem into the database and then access the data by invoking:

CREATE TABLE jokes (a INT NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY, joke
TEXT     NOT NULL);

load data infile "/foo/bar/file" into table jokes FIELDS TERMINATED BY ""
      (joke);

It is also reported that the default configuration may have the /etc/shadow file configured with group readable permissions.

A remote user with 'admin' access can exploit a flaw in the GNU tar utility [documented in a separate alert].  The tar exploit allows a user to overwrite files when expanding a tar archive.  The admin user can access the web management interface and invoke a configuration restoration from a modified tar file to install a modified /etc/passwd file on the system.  This allows the 'admin' user to gain a root shell on the device.  A demonstration exploit method is provided in the Source Message.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact':
A remote authenticated user can gain elevated privileges on the system.  Any remote user may be able to gain access if the default passwords have not been changed.

A remote authenticated user can view filesystem data, modify the configuration, and forward traffic via the device.
Solution:
The vendor has developed a fixed version (4.2.4), to be released at the end of November 2002.

The vendor reports that the following fixes were implemented in this pending version:

1. SSH port forwarding was disabled. 
2. /etc/shadow is no longer world readable
3. GNU tar is no longer used  in tftp-get.sh and tftp-put.sh scripts. We use GNU cpio instead.

Title: Iomega NAS A300u Network Storage Device May Disclose Passwords to Remote Users
Version(s): A300u; other models may be affected
Description:
Several security vulnerabilities were reported in the Iomega NAS A300u network storage device.  A remote user with access to the traffic stream can sniff the administrator password or conduct man-in-the-middle attacks against CIFS/SMB drive access.
It is reported that the web-based administration interface is not encrypted for transmission.  A remote user with access to the network traffic can obtain the administrator password, as well as the passwords of any user accounts that are created via the interface.  A company brochure apparently indicates that administrator logins are encrypted (but this report states that they are not).

For CIFS/SMB drive mounts, the default configuration allows plain text LANMAN authentication.  As a result, a remote user with access to the network inbetween the NAS and the computer using the NAS can conduct a man-in-the-middle attack to hijack the session.  Apparently, the device does not allow the administrator to disable plain text authentication.

It is reported that the FTP service cannot be disabled, even it the administrator does not want to use it.
Impact':
A remote user with the access to the network between the NAS and the administrator can obtain the administrator's password.

A remote user with the access to the network between the NAS and an associated host can   conduct man-in-the-middle attacks against CIFS/SMB shares to obtain passwords and other information.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor is reportedly working on a fix.

Title: Allot's NetEnforcer Holes Let Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges on the System
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in Allot's NetEnforcer network and application performance management system.  A local user can gain elevated privileges on the device.  A remote user may be able to gain access if the common default passwords have not been changed.
A remote user may be able to gain access to the system using common default passwords for the following accounts:  root, admin, monitor.

The following flaws can be exploited by a remote authenticated user.

A remote user with authenticated access to the 'monitor' account can user the ssh -N option (do not execute a remote command) to cause the NetEnforcer ssh daemon to forward traffic from the remote user.

A remote user can exploit the above listed flaw to access the NetEnforcer MySQL server on port 53305.  Remote access to this port is only permitted for local users 'root' and 'mysql', but the port forwarding flaw makes the access appear to be local so that a remote user (who has obtain a password for the 'admin' account) can access the MySQL server:

ssh admin@netenforcer -L 1919:127.0.0.1:53306 -v
..
mysql -h localhost -P 1919 -u root

With this access, the user can load data from the local filesystem into the database and then access the data by invoking:

CREATE TABLE jokes (a INT NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY, joke
TEXT     NOT NULL);

load data infile "/foo/bar/file" into table jokes FIELDS TERMINATED BY ""
      (joke);

It is also reported that the default configuration may have the /etc/shadow file configured with group readable permissions.

A remote user with 'admin' access can exploit a flaw in the GNU tar utility [documented in a separate alert].  The tar exploit allows a user to overwrite files when expanding a tar archive.  The admin user can access the web management interface and invoke a configuration restoration from a modified tar file to install a modified /etc/passwd file on the system.  This allows the 'admin' user to gain a root shell on the device.  A demonstration exploit method is provided in the Source Message.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact':
A remote authenticated user can gain elevated privileges on the system.  Any remote user may be able to gain access if the default passwords have not been changed.

A remote authenticated user can view filesystem data, modify the configuration, and forward traffic via the device.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Sun Cobalt Qube /usr/lib/authenticate Bug Lets Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in /usr/lib/authenticate on Sun's Cobalt RaQ and Qube platforms.  A local user could gain root privileges.
Sun did not disclose the nature of the vulnerability.  No further details were provided.

Sun Cobalt Control Station (SCCS) is also reportedly affected.
Impact': A local user could gain root privileges on the system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  Sun is working on a resolution.

Sun did not disclose the nature of the vulnerability.  No further details were provided.

Title: Gateway GS-400 Storage Server Default Configuration Weakness May Give Root Access to Remote Users
Description:
A default configuration vulnerability was reported in Gateway's GS-400 storage server.  A remote user may be able to obtain root access on the system.
It is reported that the Gateway GS-400 server runs on a customized Linux distribution and ships with a vendor default root password of "0001n".  According to the report, Gateway documents that the the end user has no way to change this vendor default password via the web based administrative utilities provided with the product.  It is also reported that other similarly weak default passwords are used.  

A remote user could attempt to login using the default root password or by cracking one of the other default passwords.
Impact': A remote user can login using the default root password if it has not been changed.  A remote user can also attempt to crack one of the other default passwords.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  According to the report, Gateway is no longer supporting the product and has permitted all owners of GS-400 servers to return them.

Title: Sun Cobalt Qube 3 Appliance Access Control Bugs Let Remote Users Access New User Accounts or Delete Files on the System and Let Local Users Gain 'Admin' Privileges
Description:
Several access control vulnerabilities were reported in the Cobalt Qube 3 system management interface.  A remote user may be able to obtain administrative access on the management interface.
It is reported that a local user with the ability to create file on the server can create a specially crafted file in the '/tmp/test' directory to mimick an authentication cookie.  A demonstration exploit command is provided:

$ printf "admin" > /tmp/test

This will allow the remote user to login with 'admin' privileges without supplying a password using the following type of command [using the 'curl' URL generation tool]:

$ curl -b sessionId=/../../../../../../tmp/test\;loginName=admin
http://192.168.0.1:444/splashAdmin.php

It is also reported that if a user account has been newly created, a remote user can login without supplying authentication credentials:

$curl -b sessionId=../codb/objects/4/.name\;loginName=admin
http://192.168.0.1:444/splashAdmin.php

According to the report, any remote user can delete arbitrary files on the server by specifying the path to the file and the first 31 characters of the file name.  A demonstration exploit command that deletes the /etc/passwd file from the server is provided:

$curl -b
sessionId=../../../../../../../../etc/passwd\;loginName=root:x:0:0:root:/root:/bin/bash 
http://192.168.0.1:444/splashAdmin.php

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can login to a newly created account without supplying a password.  A remote user can delete arbitrary files from the server.  A local user can gain 'admin' privileges.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The authors of the report have provided the following quick solution:

/usr/sausalito/ui/libPhp/ServerScriptHelper.php

line 64: 
$sessionId = ereg_replace("\.\.","",$sessionId);

Title: Pyramid Computer BenHur Server Appliance Firewall Rule Set Lets Remote Users Connect to Certain Ports on the Firewall
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the firewall function of Pyramid Computer's BenHur communications server.  A remote user may be able to connect to certain active ports on the server, including the firewall administration port
A remote user can reportedly use TCP source port 20 to connect to services on ports 1024 and above.  The report states that, with Update 066 fix 2, ports between 1024 and 65096 are vulnerabile and that, with previous releases, ports between 1024 adn 65535 are vulnerable.

In the default configuration, a remote user can potentially connect to the following ports:

3128, Squid (reportedly protected by Squid access control lists)
4557, HylaFAX client server
4559, HylaFAX client server
6105, ISDN client server monitor and connection trigger program
8888, Firewall Web administration

A remote user can connect to the firewall administration port (8888) to obtain information about the web server version and the operating system used by the appliance.  Also, a remote user could conduct a brute force password guessing attack to gain administrative access to the appliance.

The vulnerability is reportedly due to an unsafe ipchains rule set.
Impact': A remote user can obtain information about the appliance.  A remote user can conduct a brute force password guessing attack to gain administrative access to the firewall.
Solution:
The vendor has released an experimental update (067, dated 19 Jul 2002).  To update, select experimental updates by change of setting:

"configuration->admin->update-host-einstellungen->url-pfad" to "updates_experimental"

Or, download the update at:

https://www.ben-hur.de/updates_experimental

Title: (Sun Issues Workaround for Cobalt RaQ) Re: Apache mod_ssl 'Off-by-One' Bug May Let Local Users Crash the Web Server or Possibly Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): RaQ3(3000R), ManageRaQ3(3000R-mr), RaQ4(3001R), RaQ XTR(3500R), ManageRaQ v2(3599BD), Qube3(4000WG), Control Station(4100CS), Velociraptor(velociraptor); with certain versions of apache-openssl-1.3.x
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in mod_ssl.  A local user that can create '.htaccess' files may be able to cause mod_ssl to crash or execute arbitrary code on the system with the privileges of the web server.
An 'off-by-one' error has been reported in mod_ssl.  The flaw reportedly exists in the  ssl_compat_directive() while invoking the Apache web server rewrite_command extended API (EAPI) hook.  According to the report, when backward compatibility is enabled, mod_ssl registers a rewrite_command hook and calls the ssl_compat_directive() function for every line read in a configuration file.

A local user that can create a '.htaccess' file on the web server can place specially crafted information in the file to cause Apache mod_ssl to execute arbitrary code when reading the file (e.g., when a remote user attempts to access a file in a directory protected by the '.htaccess' file).

Servers that allow virtual hosts and have the "AllowOverride" directive not set to "None" for virtual hosts may be affected if local users have access to any part of the web directory.  Other configurations may also be vulnerable.

According to the report, mod_ssl compiled without backward compatibility is not vulnerable.  However, the backward compatibility feature is reportedly enabled by default during compilation.
Impact': A local user could cause denial of service conditions or could possibly execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the web server.
Solution:
Sun reports that a final resolution is pending completion.

Sun has provided the following workaround:

"The workaround is to disallow per-directory configuration files by only having "AllowOverride None" directives in your "httpd.conf" file. On most Sun Cobalt platforms this file can be found in the "/etc/httpd/conf" or "/etc/apache/conf" directory.

To activate the changes in the "httpd.conf" file, as root, you must restart the Apache web server by using the command: 

	# /etc/rc.d/init.d/httpd restart

Note: If ".htaccess" files are used to control access to restricted areas of web sites, these areas will become UNPROTECTED by this action."
Vendor URL: RaQ3(3000R), ManageRaQ3(3000R-mr), RaQ4(3001R), RaQ XTR(3500R), ManageRaQ v2(3599BD), Qube3(4000WG), Control Station(4100CS), Velociraptor(velociraptor); with certain versions of apache-openssl.

Title: (Sun Issues Workaround for Cobalt RaQ 550) Re: OpenSSH Integer Overflow and Buffer Overflow May Allow Remote Users to Gain Root Access to the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Two vulnerabilities were reported in the OpenSSH implementation of the Secure Shell SSH protocol. A remote user can obtain root access on the system in certain configurations.
ISS originally reported that a buffer overflow vulnerability exists within the "challenge-response" authentication mechanism in the OpenSSH daemon (sshd).  It has since been clarified that there are two separate but related vulnerabilities that occur in processing challenge responses.

One vulnerability is an integer overflow in the processing of the number of responses received during challenge response authentication.  If the server is configured for challenge response authentication *and* the system is using SKEY or BSD_AUTH authentication, the system may be vulnerable.  A remote user can send a specially-crafted reply to cause the daemon to crash or to execute arbitrary code with root privileges.  This flaw is reported to be present in version 2.9.9 through 3.3.

The other vulnerability is a buffer overflow in the processing of the number of responses received during challenge response authentication.  If the server is using using PAM modules that use interactive keyboard authentication (PAMAuthenticationViaKbdInt), the system may be vulnerable (however, this apparently has not been confirmed).  This flaw is reported to be present in versoin 2.3.1 through 3.3.
Impact': A remote user can obtain root level access on the system, under certain system configurations.
Solution:
Sun has provided the following workaround for the Cobalt RaQ 550:

The workaround is to disable the "ChallengeResponseAuthentication" parameter within the OpenSSH daemon configuration file, "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" by setting it to "no", as below:

	ChallengeResponseAuthentication no                                    

The "sshd" process must be restarted for this change to take effect.  This can be done by executing the following command, as root:

	# /etc/rc.d/init.d/sshd restart                                    

A final resolution is pending completion.

Title: Sun Ray Server With Non-Smartcard Mobility Feature May Allow Remote Users with XDMCP Clients to Login to an Arbitrary Users' Sun Ray Server Account
Description:
Sun reported a vulnerability in their Sun Ray appliance when used with Non-Smartcard Mobility (NSCM).  A remote user may be able to gain access to a Sun Ray user account.
A remote user may be able to use 'dtlogin' to login to a Sun Ray server that is configured to use non-smartcard mobility (NSCM) and 'inadvertently' gain access as a different user.  The remote user must be using a client that is issuing XDMCP to the Sun Ray server inorder for the exploit to work.  The remote user apparently is not required to have their own account on the Sun Ray server itself. 

Sun reports that Sun Ray Server Software (SRSS) 1.3 with CDE patch 108919-14 (for Solaris 8) and without patch 111891-05 is affected.  According to the report, SRSS 1.2 and earlier are not affected. 

To determine if a Sun Ray server is configured to use NSCM, Sun suggests running the following command and then viewing the output:

	$ /opt/SUNWut/sbin/utpolicy
	# Reading policy file: /etc/opt/SUNWut/policy/utpolicy
	# Current Policy:
	/opt/SUNWut/sbin/utpolicy -a -m -M -g -z both                                          

If the "-M" switch is present in the Current Policy display, the Sun Ray server is indeed running NSCM and could potentially be vulnerable.
Impact': A remote user on an XDMCP client may be able to login to a Sun Ray server acting as a different user.
Solution:
Sun has issued a patch for Sun Ray.  For Sun Ray Server Software (SRSS) version 1.3, apply patch 111891-05 or later.

A workaround is reportedly available, but Sun requires that you contact your local Sun Enterprise Service support representative for more information on the workaroubd.

Title: Quantum 'Snap Server' Network Attached Storage Device Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Quantum's Snap Server network attached storage (NAS) device.  A remote user can cause the device to crash with a fragmentation attack.
It is reported that a remote user can send fragmented packets to the device to cause it to crash.  For example, an 'nmap -f' can be used to trigger the vulnerability.

According to the report, this may be due to a vulnerability of the undelrying operating system used in the Snap Server (reported to be BSD-based).

It is also reported that the server uses a predictably increasing TCP sequence number, making IP spoofing attacks easier.
Impact': A remote user can cause the Snap Server storage device to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: ECS K7S5A Mainboard Lack of Access Control on Boot Menu Lets Physically Local Users Make Unauthorized Changes to the Boot Process
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the ECS K7S5A mainboards.  The mainboards fail to provide access control on the boot menu, so a physically local user can make changes to the boot process.
SecurityFocus reported a vulnerability in the K7S5A series of mainboards from Elitegroup Computer Systems of Taiwan.

According to the report, a local user with physical access to the system may be able to cause the system to boot from an alternative boot media.  This is apparently due to the lack of access controls on the boot menu.

The following firmware version is reported to be vulnerable:

ECS K7S5A(L) V.02/02/06

SecurityFocus credits Guy Van Sanden <unixmafia@flashmail.com> with discovering this flaw.

For more information on the product, see the vendor's web site:

http://www.ecs.com.tw/products/k7s5a.htm
Impact': A physically local user can change the boot process to cause the system to boot from an alternate boot media (such as a floppy diskette).
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Compaq Integrated Administrator for Compaq ProLiant Server Blade Enclosure May Allow Authenticated Remote Users to Gain Full Access to the Enclosure Operating System
Description:
Compaq reported a vulnerability in the Integrated Administrator feature for the Compaq ProLiant BL e-Class enclosure for server blades.  In certain situations, an authenticated remote user can gain full access to the enclosure.
It is reported that an authenticated remote user may be able to gain unrestricted access to the embedded operating system of the enclosure (Integrated Administrator).  The user must have either Telnet, Secure Shell, or console access to the system in order to exploit the vulnerability.  Users with only web access cannot exploit the bug, according to Compaq.

The nature of the vulnerability was not disclosed by Compaq.

According to the report, exploiting the vulnerability only gives the user access to the enclosure and not to the server blades.
Impact': A remote authenticated user may be able to gain full access to the enclosure operating system.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (1.11), available at:

http://www.compaq.com/support/files/server/us/locate/5708.html

After installing this update, the vendor strongly recommends performing the following cleanup procedure if there is any suspicion the enclosure may have been compromised by a malicious authenticated user:

Change all Integrated Administrator user passwords (including the Administrator account) Execute the command "CLEAR SSHKEY"

If you were using the SSHKEY feature, then re-install your SSH authorized key file using the "DOWNLOAD SSHKEY  <url>" command.

Title: Intel BIOS Bug Lets Physically Local Users Boot From Alternate Boot Media Even When The Supervisor Password is Set
Version(s): Intel D845HV / WN (tested on BIOS revisions P05-0022, P09-0035, P10-0038) and D845PT (tested on BIOS P01-0012) Pentium 4 motherboards
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the BIOS used on several Intel Pentium 4 motherboards.  A physically local user could boot from alternate boot media.
It is reported that a physically local user can depress the F8 key during the BIOS Post operation to allow the user to select the boot device.  This reportedly occurs even when a Supervisor password has been set in the BIOS and the "User Access Level" does not permit the user to boot from an alternate device.
Impact': A physically local user may be able to cause the device to be booted from an alternate boot media.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version, available at:

http://developer.intel.com/design/motherbd/hv/hv_bios.htm
http://developer.intel.com/design/motherbd/bg/bg_bios.htm
http://developer.intel.com/design/motherbd/wn/wn_bios.htm
http://developer.intel.com/design/motherbd/pt/pt_bios.htm

Release notes for each release are available on the pages listed above.

Title: (Cisco Hosting Solution Engine is Vulnerable) 'zlib' Shared Compression Library Contains 'Double Free()' Buffer Overflow That Lets Remote Users Cause Programs Using zlib to Crash or Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the zlib shared library, a widely used library that provides in-memory compress and decompression functions.  A remote user could cause programs using this library to crash or to execute arbitrary code on the system.
It is reported that certain types of input will cause zlib to free the same area of memory twice (i.e., perform a "double free"), resulting in a buffer overflow condition when expanding compressed input. A remote user can cause programs that process untrusted user-supplied compressed input to crash or potentially execute arbitrary code on the system. 

Cisco reports that certain versions of Cisco's Hosting Solution Engine are vulnerable because they use the affected zlib library.  The following versions are vulnerable:  1.0 and 1.3.

It is reported that Matthias Clasen <maclas@gmx.de> and Owen Taylor <otaylor@redhat.com> discovered this bug in zlib.
Impact': A remote user can cause affected programs that use zlib to process untrusted user-supplied compressed input to crash or potentially execute arbitrary code on the system.
Solution: Release 1.4 contains the fix. It will be available on April 15, 2002, according to Cisco.

Title: (Cisco Intrusion Detection System is Vulnerable) 'zlib' Shared Compression Library Contains 'Double Free()' Buffer Overflow That Lets Remote Users Cause Programs Using zlib to Crash or Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the zlib shared library, a widely used library that provides in-memory compress and decompression functions.  A remote user could cause programs using this library to crash or to execute arbitrary code on the system.
It is reported that certain types of input will cause zlib to free the same area of memory twice (i.e., perform a "double free"), resulting in a buffer overflow condition when expanding compressed input. A remote user can cause programs that process untrusted user-supplied compressed input to crash or potentially execute arbitrary code on the system. 

Cisco reports that certain versions of Cisco Intrustion Detection System are vulnerable because they use the affected zlib library.  The following versions are vulnerable: 

Cisco IDS sensor appliances (part numbers IDS-4210, IDS-4220-E and IDS-4230-xx) are vulnerable if the sensor version as reported by nrvers is in the range 3.0(1) through 3.0(5) inclusive. The C6000 IDSM (part number WS-X6381-IDS) is not vulnerable.

It is reported that Matthias Clasen <maclas@gmx.de> and Owen Taylor <otaylor@redhat.com> discovered this bug in zlib.
Impact': A remote user can cause affected programs that use zlib to process untrusted user-supplied compressed input to crash or potentially execute arbitrary code on the system.
Solution:
The vendor has developed a fixed versions, 3.1(1), which will reportedly be available on April 16, 2002.

See the Source Message for instructions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.

Title: Cobalt XTR User Interface Access Control Issue and File Uploading Authentication Bug Let Local Users Write to Files with Root Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Cobalt XTR appliance user interface.  A local user can write files to the system with root privileges.
It is reported that certain portions of the the Cobalt XTR user interface UI are not password protected (i.e., no .htaccess protection). This allows remote users to access the MultiFileUpload.php function.  Due to an authentication bug in MultiFileUploadHandler.php (which handles upload request posted from MultiFileUpload.php), a remote user can cause certain temporary files to be written on the system in the /tmp directory.  The function reportedly accepts user-supplied data to specify the upload user identity.

It is also reported that the MultiFileUpload.php file uploading code uses a predicatable Base64 temporary file name based on system time.  A local user can create a symbolic link (symlink) from the predictable temporary file name to a critical file on the system (such as /etc/passwd).  

A user can exploit both of these conditions to cause arbitrary files to be written with arbitrary privileges.  After setting up the symlink, the user can upload the target file (such as a replacement /etc/passwd file) to cause the linked file to be overwritten:

https://<cobalt_xtr_host>:81/uifc/MultFileUploadHandler.php

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A local user can write to any file with root privileges.
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report recommends creating a .htaccess file in the uifc directory as a temporary fix.

Title: Cobalt RaQ4 System Management Software Lets Remote Users View Files on the System, Conduct Cross-Site Scripting Attacks, and Cause Denial of Service Conditions
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in Sun's Cobalt RaQ 4 system management software. Remote users can traverse the directory structure and view files on the system. Remote users can cause the system management software to crash. Remote users can conduct cross-site scripting attacks. A remote user can reportedly use the system management interface to traverse the directory and view files on the server. A demonstration exploit URL is provided: http://10.0.0.1:81/.cobalt/sysManage/../admin/.htaccess A remote user can also reportedly cause the system management service to crash by sending a long URL to the 'service.cgi' script: http://10.0.0.1:81/cgi-bin/.cobalt/alert/service.cgi?service=/AAAAAAAAA...(Ax100000)...AAA The admininistrator must reportedly restart the service for it to return to normal operation. Some demonstration exploit code for the denial of service vulnerability is provided in the Source Message. A remote user can reportedly exploit the 'service.cgi' and 'alert.cgi' scripts to conduct cross-site scripting attacks against Cobalt administrators and users. A remote user can create a URL that, when loaded by a target (victim) user, will cause arbitrary javascript to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will appear to originate from the Cobalt server and will run in the security context of the server. As a result, the software can access the target user's cookies and other information associated with that Cobalt server. Some demonstration exploit URLs are provided: http://10.0.0.1:81/cgi-bin/.cobalt/alert/service.cgi?service=

Hello!

http://10.0.0.1:81/cgi-bin/.cobalt/alert/service.cgi?service= http://10.0.0.1:81/cgi-bin/.cobalt/alert/service.cgi?service= http://10.0.0.1:81/cgi-bin/.cobalt/alert/service.cgi?service= http://10.0.0.1:81/cgi-bin/.cobalt/alert/service.cgi?service=%3Cscript%3Ealert(document.location)%3C/script%3E http://10.0.0.1:81/cgi-bin/.cobalt/alert/service.cgi?service=%3Cscript%3Ealert(document.cookie)%3C/script%3E http://10.0.0.1:81/cgi-bin/.cobalt/alert/service.cgi?service= http://10.0.0.1:81/cgi-bin/.cobalt/alert/service.cgi?service= The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can view files on the system.  A remote user can cause the system management software to crash.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks against server users and administrators to steal their cookies and other personal information.
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report recommends deleting service.cgi and alert.cgi from the system or preventing these scripts from executing.

Title: Sun Ray Appliance Management Port Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Version(s): tested using SunRay server software 1.3 on Solaris 8
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability has been reported in the Sun Microsystems Sun Ray appliance.  A remote user can cause the server's management port to crash.
A remote user can cause the server's management port to crash with a simple nmap port scan:

  nmap -p 7010 [targethost]

This will cause the management port to stop accepting connections and may cause existing management connections to drop.

The following is the log file entry caused by the above nmap scan:

Dec 14 07:21:09 brnray utauthd: [ID 250799 user.info] CallBack0 UNEXPECTED:
Cannot accept on socket: java.net.SocketException: Software caused
connection abort
Impact': A remote user can cause the Sun Ray appliance's management port to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: NetCache Appliance May Let Remote Users Tunnel Through the Appliance
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in Network Appliance's NetCache.  The security hole alters the configuration so that remote users can tunnel through the appliance to any TCP port.
NetCache has a 'config.http.tunnel.allow_ports' configuration option that is reportedly set by default to '+all', allowing a remote user to tunnel through the cache appliance to any TCP port.  

To determine if your system is affected, an administrator can apparently connect to the console of the NetCache (not to the HTML gui) and type 'show config.http.tunnel.allow_ports'.  If the response is '+all', then TCP port tunneling is permitted.  If the response is '!all', then tunneling is not permitted.

The report indicates that this default condition may have been caused by upgrading from v4 to v5, where the upgrade process replaces a NULL value with '+all' instead of '!all'.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can tunnel through the appliance to any TCP port.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Vendor Responds) Re: Beck IPC's IPC@CHIP Embedded Web Server Contains Multiple Flaws Allowing Remote Users to Crash the Server and Obtain Sensitive Information from the Server, Including Usernames and Passwords
Version(s): The version that comes in the DK40 evaluation kit, presumably other versions too
Description:
Sentry Research Labs reported several vulnerabilities in the IPC@CHIP embedded web server (on a chip) from Beck IPC.  These allow remote users to crash the server, obtain sensitive information from the server (including passwords), and obtain access to the server.
The vendor has responded to the original report, indicating items that must be fixed in future versions, items that can be mitigated through proper configuration, and items that the vendor does not regard as a risk or was unable to reproduce.

See the Source Message for the vendor's response.

See the Message History for the original report.
Impact': A remote user can obtain usernames and passwords from the web server or readily guess user names and passwords on the telnet server, can cause the web server to momentarily stop processing, and can cause the server to become overloaded.
Solution: The vendor responds that some items can be mitigated with proper configuration and that some items will be corrected in a future version.

Title: Beck IPC's IPC@CHIP Embedded Web Server Contains Multiple Flaws Allowing Remote Users to Crash the Server and Obtain Sensitive Information from the Server, Including Usernames and Passwords
Version(s): The version that comes in the DK40 evaluation kit, presumably other versions too
Description:
Sentry Research Labs reported several vulnerabilities in the IPC@CHIP embedded web server (on a chip) from Beck IPC.  These allow remote users to crash the server, obtain sensitive information from the server (including passwords), and obtain access to the server.
The following vulnerabilities have been reported.

The chip's telnet server does not log failed authentication attempts and does not limit successive failed attempts, allowing remote users to attempt brute force password guessing attempts without detection or delay.  

In addition, the telnet server only allows one user at a time, and there is no session timeout set by default, allowing a remote user to deny service to other telnet users.  

Furthermore, the telnet server will validate usernames before asking for the password, allowing remote users to determine valid user names on the server.

The web server's root directory is reportedly set to "/" by default.  A remote user can download the "chip.ini" file, which contains all usernames and paswords by using the following URL:  http://[targethost]/chip.ini

If a lengthy request is sent to the web server, the server will stop responding for a few moments.

A CGI script called "ChipCfg", which is installed by deafult and cannot be removed, discloses network data to any remote user using the following URL:  http://[targethost]/ChipCfg

The server can reportedly accommodate only 64 socket connections, so it can be subjected to a denial of service attack with relative ease.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can obtain usernames and passwords from the web server or readily guess user names and passwords on the telnet server, can cause the web server to momentarily stop processing, and can cause the server to become overloaded.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the report provides some suggested work arounds (see the Source Message for details).
